functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

msg.content: Who are the founders of the five largest companies by revenue in 2023?
Who are the founders of the five largest companies by revenue in 2023?

functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: You shouldn't delegate the entire task to a helper. Handle it yourself, or if it's still too complex, try breaking it up into smaller steps and call this again.

<fragment>
![](image)Walmart has been the world's largest company by revenue since 2014.[1]
This list comprises the world's largest companies by consolidated revenue, according to the *Fortune* Global 500 2023 rankings and other sources.[2] American retail corporation Walmart has been the world's largest company by revenue since 2014.[1]


The list is limited to the top 50 companies, all of which have annual revenues exceeding US$130 billion. This list is incomplete, as not all companies disclose their information to the media and/or general public.[3]


Out of 50 largest companies 20 are American, 19 Asian and 11 European.[2]




## List[edit]


Information in the list relates to the most recent fiscal year (mostly FY 2022 or 2023)

msg.content:
Based on the information retrieved, the five largest companies by revenue in 2023 are:

1. **Walmart**
2. **Saudi Aramco**
3. **State Grid Corporation of China**
4. **Amazon**
5. **Vitol**

Next, I will find the founders of these companies.

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Walmart</title>
<fragment>
50. **^** "Walmart Annual Report 2000" (PDF). p. 18. Archived (PDF) from the original on January 17, 2013. Retrieved December 8, 2012.
51. **^** "Fortune 500 2007". *Fortune*. April 16, 2007. Archived from the original on June 14, 2007. Retrieved July 15, 2007.
52. **^** "Fortune 500 2006". *Fortune*. April 17, 2006. Archived from the original on July 5, 2007. Retrieved July 15, 2007.
53. **^** "Fortune 500 2008". *Fortune*. Archived from the original on April 10, 2014.
54. **^** "Fortune 500 2009". *Fortune*. Archived from the original on April 10, 2014.
55. **^** "Fortune 500 2010". *Fortune*. Archived from the original on March 29, 2014.
56. **^** "Fortune 500 2011". *Fortune*. Archived from the original on March 29, 2014.
57. **^** "Fortune 500 2012". *Fortune*. May 9, 2014. Archived from the original on September 9, 2017. Retrieved October 25, 2017.
58. **^** "Fortune 500 2013". *Fortune*. May 22, 2014. Archived from the original on August 31, 2017. Retrieved October 25, 2017.

</fragment>
<fragment>

Walmart is the world's largest company by revenue, with about US$570 billion in annual revenue, according to the *Fortune* Global 500 list in October 2022.[14] It is also the largest private employer in the world with 2.2 million employees. It is a publicly traded family-owned business, as the company is controlled by the Walton family. Sam Walton's heirs own over 50 percent of Walmart through both their holding company Walton Enterprises and their individual holdings.[15] Walmart was the largest United States grocery retailer in 2019, and 65 percent of Walmart's US$510.329 billion sales came from U.S. operations.[16][17]


</fragment>
<fragment>
* 43.00% (1,415,891,131): Walton Enterprises LLC
* 5.30% (174,563,205): Walton family Holdings Trust[398]
* 3.32% (102,036,399): The Vanguard Group, Inc
* 2.37% (72,714,226): State Street Corporation

* 0.65% (20,125,838): Bank of America Corporation

* 0.57% (17,556,128): Northern Trust Corporation
* 0.55% (16,818,165): Vanguard Institutional Index Fund-Institutional Index Fund
* 0.55% (16,800,850): State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co
* 0.52% (15,989,827): SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust


### Competition[edit]

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Saudi Aramco</title>
<fragment>
61. **^** "Saudi Aramco kick-starts what could be world's biggest IPO, offers scant details". *Reuters*. 3 November 2019. Archived from the original on 3 November 2019. Retrieved 3 November 2019.
62. **^** Graham, Holly Ellyatt,Emma (3 November 2019). "Saudi Arabia formally announces Aramco IPO with a domestic listing set for December". *CNBC*. Archived from the original on 3 November 2019. Retrieved 3 November 2019.`{{cite web}}`: CS1 maint: multiple names: authors list (link)
63. **^** "Saudi Aramco will provide lower than 1% of its shares to particular person traders. It nonetheless could be the most important IPO ever". *Business News*. 28 August 2019. Archived from the original on 11 November 2019. Retrieved 10 November 2019.
64. **^** Julia Horowitz and John Defterios (5 December 2019). "Saudi Aramco raises $25.6 billion in the world's biggest IPO". *CNN*. Retrieved 5 December 2019.

</fragment>
<fragment>
9. **^** OPEC, Annual Statistical Bulletin 2016 Archived 21 August 2018 at the Wayback Machine
10. **^** "International - U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)". *www.eia.gov*. Retrieved 24 March 2020.
11. **^** Saudi Arabia - Overview (PDF) (Report). Energy Information Administration. 20 October 2017. Archived (PDF) from the original on 11 May 2019. Retrieved 16 September 2019.
12. **^** "How real is Saudi Arabia's interest in renewable energy?". *the Guardian*. 12 October 2019.
13. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** Aramco Overseas Company - About Saudi Aramco Archived 18 October 2014 at the Wayback Machine, aramcooverseas.com. Retrieved 11 November 2014.
14. **^** "Saudi Aramco becomes most valuable listed company in history". *The Guardian*. 11 December 2019.
15. **^** Riley, Charles (12 December 2019). "The world has its first $2 trillion company. But for how long?". *CNN*. Retrieved 20 January 2020.

</fragment>
<fragment>

In 2019, sources told the Financial Times that wealthy families of Saudi Arabia had been coerced into joining the Saudi Aramco IPO.[126][127] According to analysts, Aramco could realistically reach a market capitalization of $1 to $1.5 trillion but the Saudis wanted $2 trillion. Oddly, many of those who signed up have relatives that were part of the 2017–2019 Saudi Arabian purge. According to four sources, the Saudi government "strong-armed", "coerced" or "bullied" some of the wealthiest families in the kingdom into becoming cornerstone investors.[*citation needed*]



## Lobbying and research projects[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

1. ^ ***a*** ***b*** "Saudi Arabian Oil Company (Saudi Aramco)". *Forbes*. Retrieved 12 June 2023.
2. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** ***e*** "Saudi Aramco Annual Report 2022" (PDF). Retrieved 21 March 2023.
3. **^** "Saudi Aramco raises $37.48 billion in the world's biggest IPO". CNN Business. 25 September 2019.
4. **^** "ARAMCO Institutional Ownership - Saudi Arabian Oil Co". *fintel.io*.
5. **^** "Key facts and figures". Saudi Aramco. Archived from the original on 6 June 2017. Retrieved 28 April 2017.
6. **^** "Our company. At a glance". Saudi Aramco. Archived from the original on 17 October 2018. Retrieved 3 August 2011. The Saudi Arabian Oil Co. (Saudi Aramco) is the state-owned oil company of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.
7. **^** Malsin, Jared; Said, Summer (16 April 2023). "Saudi Arabia Transfers Nearly $78 Billion of Aramco Shares to Wealth Fund". *Wall Street Journal*. ISSN 0099-9660. Retrieved 23 October 2023.
8. **^** "Global 500 2020". *Fortune*. Retrieved 16 December 2020.

</fragment>
<fragment>
| Number of employees
 | 66,800[5] (June 2020) |
| Subsidiaries | SABIC (70%), Petro Rabigh, SATORP, Aramco Trading, Yanbu, Yasref, SASREF, S-Oil, Luberef, Aro Drilling, South Rub al-Khali, Pengerang Refining Company, The International Maritime Industries |
| Website | aramco.com |


**Saudi Aramco** (Arabic: أرامكو السعودية **ʾArāmkū as-Suʿūdiyyah**), officially the **Saudi Arabian Oil Group** or simply **Aramco**, is a petroleum and natural gas company that is the national oil company of Saudi Arabia.[6][7] As of 2022[update], it is the second-largest company in the world by revenue[8] and is headquartered in Dhahran. It has repeatedly achieved the largest annual profits in global corporate history. Saudi Aramco has both the world's second-largest proven crude oil reserves, at more than 270 billion barrels (43 billion cubic metres),[9] and largest daily oil production of all oil-producing companies.[10][11][12]


</fragment>
</document>
msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>State Grid Corporation of China</title>
<fragment>

1. **^** "State Grid's 2017 financial report". Statista. Archived from the original on 18 December 2018. Retrieved 4 June 2018.
2. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** "State Grid". Fortune Global 500. Archived from the original on 2 May 2017. Retrieved 29 April 2017.
3. **^** "State Grid's Competitors, Revenue, Number of Employees, Funding, Acquisitions & News - Owler Company Profile".
4. **^** "State Grid | 2021 Global 500".
5. **^** "Fortune 500".
6. **^** JamesPaton14, James Paton (31 March 2016). "China Builds an Empire of Electricity With Australia as Target". *Bloomberg.com*. Archived from the original on 2016-08-12. Retrieved 2016-08-11.`{{cite news}}`: CS1 maint: numeric names: authors list (link)
7. **^** Gee, Robert; Songbin Zhu; Xiaolin Li, *China's power sector: Global economic and environmental implications*

</fragment>
<fragment>

The **State Grid Corporation of China** (**SGCC**), commonly known as the **State Grid**, is a Chinese state-owned electric utility corporation. It is the largest utility company in the world. As of 2022[update], State Grid is the world's third largest company overall by revenue, behind Walmart and Saudi Aramco.[5] In 2022 it was reported as having 871,145 employees, 1.1 billion customers and revenue equivalent to US$460 billion. It is overseen by the State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council.


After the electricity Plant-Grid Separation reform in early 2002, the assets of State Electric Power Corporation (国家电力公司) were divided into five power generation groups that retained the power plants and five regional subsidiaries belonging to the State Grid Corporation of China in Beijing.[6]

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Vitol</title>
<fragment>

1. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** "Meet The Mysterious Trading Firms Who Control The Price Of Commodities". *BusinessNews*. 2011-10-31. Retrieved 2012-03-04.
2. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** Schneyer, Joshua (2011-10-28). "Commodity Traders: The trillion dollar club". *Reuters*. Retrieved 2012-04-11.
3. **^** "Top ten global oil and commodities traders". April 15, 2011 – via www.telegraph.co.uk.
4. **^** Hoffman, Andy and Blas, Javier. "Top Trader Vitol Has New CEO as Taylor Becomes Chairman", *Bloomberg*, 15 March 2018. Retrieved on 16 March 2018.
5. **^** Dareen, Seher; Shivaprasad, Ashitha (20 March 2023). "Commodities trader Vitol's turnover jumps over 80% in 2022". *Reuters*. Retrieved 1 April 2023.
6. **^** Hook, Leslie; Sheppard, David; Packard, Jim (30 March 2023). "Vitol profits soar to record $15bn on back of energy crisis". *Financial Times*. Retrieved 1 April 2023.
7. **^** "Where we work". *Vitol*.
8. **^** "Operating globally". *Vitol*. Retrieved 2022-11-25.

</fragment>
<fragment>
9. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** McNair, Ros (2022-03-21). "Vitol 2021 volumes and review". *Vitol*. Retrieved 2022-11-24.
10. **^** "Global 500". *Fortune*. Retrieved 2022-11-24.
11. **^** Blas, Javier (23 April 2012). "Oil traders face heat over disclosure". *Financial Times*. Retrieved 26 November 2022.
12. **^** Blas, Javier (19 March 2015). "Vitol Said to Post Highest Profit Since 2011 as Oil Prices Swing". Bloomberg. Retrieved 18 October 2015.
13. **^** Schneyer, Joshua (28 October 2011). "Corrected: Commodity Traders: The trillion dollar club". *Reuters*. Retrieved 28 October 2011.
14. **^** Hume, Neil (19 March 2015). "Oil trader Vitol's profits rebound to $1.35bn". *Financial Times*. Retrieved 16 October 2015.
15. **^** "Oil trader Vitol hands top staff equivalent of $7m each". *Financial Times*. 2021-07-23. Retrieved 2022-11-24.
16. **^** O'Keefe, Brian. "The unseen hand that moves the world's oil". *Fortune*. Retrieved 28 February 2013.

</fragment>
<fragment>

With revenues of $505 billion in 2022,[9] Vitol is the largest independent energy trader in the world, and would be the second-largest company worldwide as measured by revenue on the *Fortune* Global 500 list.[10] Given the secrecy Vitol maintains around all its business activities and the limited nature of its statutory disclosures,[11] it is excluded from rankings. The company, however, does provide some more financial information to its lenders and to a few other entities with which it trades.[12] The company ships more than 350 million tonnes of crude oil per year and controls 250 supertankers and other vessels to move it around the world. On average it handles more than 7.6 million barrels a day of oil and products, [9] roughly equivalent to the daily consumption of Japan, the world's fourth-largest oil consumer after the United States, China, and India.[13][14]


</fragment>
<fragment>
Dutch energy and commodity trading company

| Company type | Private |
| Industry | Commodity, Oil & Gas |
| Founded | 1966; 58 years ago (1966)Rotterdam, Netherlands[1] |

| Number of locations
 | ![Increase](image) 40 |
| Area served
 | Global |
| Key people

| Services | Energy & Commodities, Shipping & Chartering, Terminals & Storage, Exploration & Production, Power Generation |
| Revenue | ![Increase](image) US$505 billion (2022)[5] |
| Net income
 | ![Increase](image) US$15 billion (2022)[6] |
| Owner | Vitol Holding II S.A. |
| Number of employees
 | 1,600+ [7] |
| Website | www.vitol.com |


</fragment>
<fragment>

In 2020, Vitol Inc. agreed to pay a combined total criminal penalty of $135 million to resolve bribery charges with law enforcement authorities in the United States and Brazil.[41][42][43] The resolution arises out of Vitol schemes to pay bribes to officials in Brazil, Ecuador and Mexico.[41]



## Vitol Asia Pte Ltd[edit]


Vitol Asia Pte Ltd operates as an energy and commodities company, and offers refining, trading, shipping, and storage of crude oil and energy products.[44]


The company was founded in April 1990 and is headquartered in Singapore. The CEO of this subsidiary has been Mike Muller since 10 September 2019.[45]



## References[edit]

</document>

msg.content:
Here are the founders of the five largest companies by revenue in 2023:

1. **Walmart**: Founded by Sam Walton.
2. **Saudi Aramco**: Saudi Aramco does not have a single founder as it was established by the Saudi government. It evolved from the Arabian American Oil Company, which was a joint venture between the Saudi government and American oil companies.
3. **State Grid Corporation of China**: This company is a state-owned enterprise and does not have a traditional founder. It was established by the Chinese government.
4. **Amazon**: Founded by Jeff Bezos.
5. **Vitol**: Founded by Henk Viëtor and Jacques Detiger.
